title: Pound falls as disappointing retail sales figures weigh on growth hopes
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Aug 20, 2015, 12:43 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 47 mins Pound falls as disappointing retail sales figures weigh on growth hopes By Peter Spence | Telegraph â€“ 12 minutes ago 58.45 -0.64 
Consumers are buying more in the high street, but lower prices mean the value of retail sales is barely rising 
British shoppers are buying more in stores this summer as they enjoy low prices - but overall retail sales disappointed in July. 
Retail sales in the UK grew by 0.1pc compared with the previous month, according to the Office for National Statistics, disappointing experts who had expected growth to be four times stronger. 
As a result, retail's contribution to the UK's economic growth is now expected to decline in the latter part of the year. The unexpected weakness sent sterling sharply down against the dollar on Thursday. 
The pound fell by 0.45pc against the US currency, as investors bet that the disappointing retail sales figures could mean that the Bank of England waits even longer to raise its interest rates. 
The headline retail sales number was dragged down by a 2.6pc drop in fuel sales. But excluding fuel, overall sales rose by a more solid 0.4pc, with department stores and household goods shops performing particulary well. 
The fall in energy costs and an ongoing price war in Britain's major supermarkets meant that average prices dropped by 3pc in July compared with the same month a year earlier, which means shoppers' cash is going further. 
Sales volumes - the amount of goods sold - increased by 4.2pc in July compared with the same month a year earlier, marking the 28th month of year-on-year growth - although economists had hoped for a rise of 4.4pc. 
John Hawksworth, chief economist at PwC, said: "Retail sales volumes continued to grow in July, but the pace of expansion has slowed from the very strong rates recorded earlier in late 2014 and early 2015." 
"The figures suggest that consumer spending will remain a positive contributor to economic growth in the third quarter, but at a more moderate pace than earlier in the year," Mr Hawksworth said. 
Dominic Bryant, an economist at BNP Paribas (Xetra: 887771 - news ) , was more optimistic, saying that the "recent fall in oil prices should support real incomes and, therefore, retail sales in the coming months". 
He said: "Consumer spending seems likely to grow by around 3pc this year, which should support GDP growth of 2.5pc."
